content.html: I propose in the present memoir to consider the theory of matrices, and in connection therewith the theory of linear transformations.

poll.question: Why does Cayley immediately connect matrices with linear transformations?
options: Because matrices encode systems of linear equations as single algebraic objects.
Because matrices were originally invented for calculus.
Because determinants only apply to transformations.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: A matrix is formed from a rectangular array of quantities, arranged in rows and columns.

poll.question: What conceptual shift does this definition introduce?
options: Treating an array of numbers as a single algebraic entity.
Restricting matrices to square form only.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: Two matrices may be said to be equal when the corresponding elements are equal.

poll.question: What structure does this equality preserve?

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The addition of matrices is effected by adding together the corresponding elements.

poll.question: Why is matrix addition commutative?
options: Because real number addition is commutative entrywise.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The product of two matrices is defined by a law of combination which depends upon the multiplication and addition of the elements.

poll.question: Why is matrix multiplication not generally commutative?
options: Because row-by-column combination depends on order.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: If we denote the matrix by A, and the matrix by B, the product AB is in general different from BA.

poll.question: What deeper idea is hinted at here?

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: There exists a particular matrix, which may be called the unit-matrix, such that its product with any other matrix leaves that matrix unaltered.

poll.question: What algebraic role does the unit-matrix play?

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The determinant vanishes when the rows or columns are linearly dependent.

poll.question: What does a vanishing determinant imply?

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: If the determinant of a matrix does not vanish, the matrix possesses an inverse.

poll.question: Why does non-zero determinant guarantee an inverse?
options: Because the matrix equation \( AX = I \) has a unique solution.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: Every square matrix satisfies its own characteristic equation.

poll.question: This statement is now known as:

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: Marx devoted considerable effort during the last years of his life to the study of mathematics, especially the foundations of differential calculus. These studies were not incidental but reflected a deeper concern with the logical structure of scientific reasoning.

poll.question: According to Dauben, why did Marx study the foundations of calculus so intensely?
options: He aimed to compute new numerical tables.
He saw foundational questions as revealing the logical structure of scientific reasoning.
He wanted to replace Newton’s physics.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: For Marx, mathematics was not politically neutral. Its development was shaped by historical and social forces, and its concepts reflected the dialectical processes that governed material reality.

poll.question: What larger claim is Dauben attributing to Marx here?
options: Mathematical concepts are historically and socially conditioned.
Mathematics is purely objective and timeless.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The problem of infinitesimals had long troubled mathematicians. Marx was particularly interested in the logical contradictions embedded in their early formulations and sought to expose their conceptual weaknesses.

poll.question: What logical difficulty made infinitesimals controversial?
options: They were treated as both zero and non-zero simultaneously.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: In examining expressions such as \(\frac{dy}{dx}\), Marx questioned whether infinitesimals were genuine quantities or merely symbolic devices masking deeper logical transformations.

poll.question: What issue does the expression \(\frac{dy}{dx}\) raise in Marx’s analysis?
options: Whether it represents a true ratio of quantities or the result of a limiting process.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Marx regarded the transition from finite difference quotients to derivatives as an example of dialectical transformation, where quantitative change gives rise to qualitative difference.

poll.question: In dialectical terms, what does the passage from \(\Delta y/\Delta x\) to \(dy/dx\) represent?
options: A qualitative transformation emerging from quantitative variation.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The limit concept, formalized in the nineteenth century, resolved many earlier ambiguities surrounding infinitesimals. Yet Marx’s notebooks reveal that he was less concerned with formalism than with logical clarity.

poll.question: How did nineteenth-century limit theory change the status of infinitesimals?
options: It proved infinitesimals are prime numbers.
It replaced them with rigorously defined limiting processes.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Mao later embraced mathematics as a tool of revolutionary transformation, insisting that theory must be united with practice. Mathematical education became part of broader ideological reform.

poll.question: What tension during the Cultural Revolution shaped attitudes toward mathematics?
options: Suspicion of abstraction versus demand for practical application.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The politics of infinitesimals thus extended beyond technical mathematics. They became emblematic of debates over abstraction, rigor, and the social function of science.

poll.question: Why did infinitesimals become politically significant in China?
options: They symbolized deeper debates about abstraction and ideology in science.
They were used in military engineering.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Expressions like \(\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}\) represent the culmination of centuries of effort to clarify the foundations of calculus.

poll.question: What conceptual advance does this limit expression embody?
options: Replacing infinitesimal ratios with a rigorously defined limiting process.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The reflections which form the subject of this little treatise date from the autumn of the year 1858... I formed the fixed resolve to reflect until I had found a purely arithmetical and completely rigorous foundation for the principles of infinitesimal analysis.

poll.question: What foundational theorem does Dedekind later show is equivalent to the principle of continuity?
options: That every polynomial has a root.
That every bounded increasing sequence has a limit.
That every rational number has a decimal expansion.

content.html: By arithmetic I understand the science of numbers... subtraction and division shall always be possible.

poll.question: Why were negative and rational numbers introduced according to Dedekind?
options: To remove the restrictions of subtraction and division.

content.html: The rational numbers form an ordered field; but they do not suffice to express every magnitude...

poll.question: What example does Dedekind later use to demonstrate this insufficiency?
options: The square root of a non-square integer.

content.html: Let D be a positive integer which is not the square of an integer... No rational number whose square equals D exists.

poll.question: Why does this example lead to a Dedekind cut without a greatest element?
options: Because rationals with square less than D have no maximum.

content.html: If all points of a straight line fall into two classes... there exists one and only one point which produces this division.

poll.question: What is remarkable about Dedekind’s treatment of this statement?
options: He declares it an axiom defining continuity.

content.html: Every cut of the rational numbers... determines either a rational or an irrational number.

poll.question: What guarantees that each cut corresponds to exactly one number?
options: The definition of equality via identical lower sets.

content.html: Whenever a cut is given which is not produced by a rational number, we create a new number...

poll.question: What philosophical stance does this reflect?
options: Numbers are created by definition, not discovered geometrically.

content.html: The totality of all real numbers forms a complete ordered field...

poll.question: Which additional property distinguishes \(\mathbb{R}\) from \(\mathbb{Q}\)?
options: Every cut of \(\mathbb{R}\) is produced by a number.

content.html: If \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are real numbers corresponding to cuts... their sum is defined by a corresponding cut.

poll.question: Why does Dedekind define addition via cuts rather than decimal expansions?
options: To reduce operations entirely to rational arithmetic.

content.html: The order of the real numbers is such that if \(\alpha > \beta\) and \(\beta > \gamma\), then \(\alpha > \gamma\).

poll.question: What does this ensure about the structure of \(\mathbb{R}\)?
options: It forms a totally ordered set.

content.html: If S be a divisor of N, then there is a conjugate divisor S' such that SS' = N. Thus we see that the number of divisors from 1 to \( \sqrt{N} \) is equal to the number of divisors from \( \sqrt{N} \) to N.

poll.question: Why does Ramanujan restrict attention to divisors up to \( \sqrt{N} \)?
options: Because every divisor greater than \( \sqrt{N} \) is paired with a unique conjugate divisor less than \( \sqrt{N} \).
Because all divisors of N are less than or equal to \( \sqrt{N} \).
Because prime divisors must lie below \( \sqrt{N} \).

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: Let \( N = p_1^{a_1} p_2^{a_2} \dots p_n^{a_n} \), where \( p_1, p_2, \dots, p_n \) are primes. Then it is easy to see that \( d(N) = (1+a_1)(1+a_2)\dots(1+a_n) \).

poll.question: If \( N = p^4 q^2 \), what does Ramanujan’s formula give for \( d(N) \)?

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: Since the arithmetic mean of unequal positive numbers is always greater than their geometric mean, we obtain inequalities which give a superior limit for \( d(N) \).

poll.question: What is the purpose of invoking the arithmetic–geometric mean inequality here?
options: To prove that primes are infinite.
To derive an upper bound for \( d(N) \).

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: If \( p \) be the largest prime not exceeding \( x \), then bounds for \( d(N) \) may be expressed in terms of the product \( \log 2 \log 3 \log 5 \dots \log p \).

poll.question: Why do logarithms of primes appear in Ramanujan’s bound?
options: Because \( \log(p_1 p_2 \dots p_n) = \log p_1 + \dots + \log p_n \), allowing multiplicative structure to be analyzed additively.
Because primes are defined using logarithms.

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: The symbol \( O \) is used in the following sense: \( f(x) = O(\phi(x)) \) means that there is a positive constant \( K \) such that \( |f(x)| \leq K \phi(x) \) for all sufficiently large values of \( x \).

poll.question: According to Ramanujan’s definition, what does \( f(x) = O(\phi(x)) \) guarantee?
options: That \( f(x) \) eventually grows no faster than a constant multiple of \( \phi(x) \).
That \( f(x) \) is bounded for all x.

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

posts.caption: An example of change ringing (with six bells), one of the earliest nontrivial results in graph theory.
posts.credit: Public domain (PD-self). Commons lists: source assumed own work; author assumed Andrew Hyde (based on copyright claims).

posts.caption: Hasse diagram of the powerset of \( \{x,y,z\} \) ordered by inclusion.
posts.credit: Created by KSmrq; self-made using graphviz's dot. Licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0 (also offered under other free licenses on the Commons page).

posts.caption: Five binary trees on three vertices, an example of Catalan numbers.
posts.credit: Transferred from Spanish Wikipedia to Commons. Commons lists the original uploader as Jasampler; file page indicates public domain status for this simple-geometry diagram.

posts.caption: Kissing spheres are connected to both coding theory and discrete geometry.
posts.credit: Transferred from English Wikipedia to Commons; Commons lists the original uploader as Robertwb. Licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0.

posts.caption: Graph theory in sociology: Moreno Sociogram (1953).
posts.creator: Martin Grandjean

posts.caption: A graph with 6 vertices and 7 edges.
posts.creator: Michel Bakni

posts.caption: The Seven Bridges of Königsberg problem.
posts.credit: Public domain (PD), based on the image.
posts.creator: Bogdan Giuşcă

posts.caption: The manipulations of the Rubik's Cube form the Rubik's Cube group.
posts.credit: Created by RTCNCA, licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0 via Wikimedia Commons

posts.caption: Set of hours in a clock, \( \{0,1,\dots,11\} \), is isomorphic to \( C_{12} \) (arithmetic modulo 12) e.g. \( 9 + 4 = 1 \).
posts.credit: Uploaded by Spindled, licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0 via Wikimedia Commons

posts.caption: A periodic wallpaper pattern gives rise to a wallpaper group.
posts.credit: Public domain; originally by Owen Jones, from The Grammar of Ornament (1856), via Wikimedia Commons

posts.caption: The fundamental group of a plane minus a point (bold) consists of loops around the missing point. This group is isomorphic to the integers under addition \( \mathbb{Z} \).
posts.credit: Created by Jakob.scholbach (original) and redrawn by Pbroks13, licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0 via Wikimedia Commons

posts.caption: A Lehmer sieve, a primitive digital computer used to find primes and solve simple Diophantine equations.
posts.creator: Marcin Wichary from San Francisco, Calif.

posts.caption: Corrections to an estimate of the prime-counting function using zeros of the zeta function.
posts.creator: Daniel Hutama

posts.caption: The Babylonians demonstrated an early understanding of Pythagorean triples.
posts.creator: photo author unknown

posts.caption: The action of the modular group on the upper half plane. The region in grey is the standard fundamental domain.
posts.creator: Original: Kilom691; Vector: Alexander Hulpke

posts.caption: Riemann zeta function \( \zeta(s) \) in the complex plane. The color of a point \( s \) gives the value of \( \zeta(s) \): dark colors denote values close to zero and hue gives the value's argument.
posts.creator: Jan Homann

posts.caption: Fermat is sometimes considered the founder of modern number theory.

Set inclusions between the natural numbers (\( \mathbb{N} \)), the integers (\( \mathbb{Z} \)), the rational numbers (\( \mathbb{Q} \)), the real numbers (\( \mathbb{R} \)), and the complex numbers (\( \mathbb{C} \)).
posts.credit: Own work based on: Number-systems with C.png.
posts.creator: Mortalmoth

posts.caption: Real numbers \( \mathbb{R} \) include the rational numbers \( \mathbb{Q} \), which include the integers \( \mathbb{Z} \), which in turn include the natural numbers \( \mathbb{N} \).
posts.creator: Mortalmoth

posts.caption: Real numbers can be thought of as all points on a number line.
posts.creator: User:Phrood~commonswiki

authors.name: Arthur Cayley
authors.bio: English mathematician who founded the abstract theory of matrices.

authors.name: Joseph W. Dauben
authors.bio: Historian of mathematics known for work on Marx, Mao, and the politics of infinitesimals.

authors.name: Richard Dedekind
authors.bio: German mathematician who gave a rigorous arithmetical construction of the real numbers via cuts.

authors.name: Srinivasa Ramanujan
authors.bio: Indian mathematician known for extraordinary contributions to number theory, infinite series, and asymptotic formulas.

authors.name: Wikipedia
authors.bio: Free online encyclopedia containing collaboratively written and edited articles.

works.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices
Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals
On the Number of Divisors of a Number

dedekind.name: Richard Dedekind
dedekind.bio: German mathematician who gave a rigorous arithmetical construction of the real numbers via cuts.

ramanujan.name: Srinivasa Ramanujan
ramanujan.bio: Indian mathematician known for extraordinary contributions to number theory, infinite series, and asymptotic formulas.

searchIndex.text: i propose in the present memoir to consider the theory of matrices and in connection therewith the theory of linear transformations linear algebra matrices foundations a memoir on the theory of matrices arthur cayley
a matrix is formed from a rectangular array of quantities arranged in rows and columns linear algebra matrices foundations a memoir on the theory of matrices arthur cayley
two matrices may be said to be equal when the corresponding elements are equal linear algebra matrices foundations a memoir on the theory of matrices arthur cayley
the addition of matrices is effected by adding together the corresponding elements linear algebra matrices foundations a memoir on the theory of matrices arthur cayley

the product of two matrices is defined by a law of combination which depends upon the multiplication and addition of the elements linear algebra matrices foundations a memoir on the theory of matrices arthur cayley
if we denote the matrix by a and the matrix by b the product ab is in general different from ba linear algebra matrices foundations a memoir on the theory of matrices arthur cayley

there exists a particular matrix which may be called the unit matrix such that its product with any other matrix leaves that matrix unaltered linear algebra matrices foundations a memoir on the theory of matrices arthur cayley
the determinant vanishes when the rows or columns are linearly dependent linear algebra matrices foundations a memoir on the theory of matrices arthur cayley
if the determinant of a matrix does not vanish the matrix possesses an inverse linear algebra matrices foundations a memoir on the theory of matrices arthur cayley
every square matrix satisfies its own characteristic equation linear algebra matrices foundations a memoir on the theory of matrices arthur cayley

marx devoted considerable effort during the last years of his life to the study of mathematics especially the foundations of differential calculus these studies were not incidental but reflected a deeper concern with the logical structure of scientific reasoning foundations calculus marxism marx mao and mathematics the politics of infinitesimals joseph w dauben

for marx mathematics was not politically neutral its development was shaped by historical and social forces and its concepts reflected the dialectical processes that governed material reality marxism dialectics foundations marx mao and mathematics the politics of infinitesimals joseph w dauben

the problem of infinitesimals had long troubled mathematicians marx was particularly interested in the logical contradictions embedded in their early formulations and sought to expose their conceptual weaknesses calculus infinitesimals foundations marx mao and mathematics the politics of infinitesimals joseph w dauben

in examining expressions such as frac dy dx marx questioned whether infinitesimals were genuine quantities or merely symbolic devices masking deeper logical transformations calculus infinitesimals real analysis marx mao and mathematics the politics of infinitesimals joseph w dauben

marx regarded the transition from finite difference quotients to derivatives as an example of dialectical transformation where quantitative change gives rise to qualitative difference dialectics calculus foundations marx mao and mathematics the politics of infinitesimals joseph w dauben

the limit concept formalized in the nineteenth century resolved many earlier ambiguities surrounding infinitesimals yet marx s notebooks reveal that he was less concerned with formalism than with logical clarity real analysis limits foundations marx mao and mathematics the politics of infinitesimals joseph w dauben

mao later embraced mathematics as a tool of revolutionary transformation insisting that theory must be united with practice mathematical education became part of broader ideological reform maoism marxism education marx mao and mathematics the politics of infinitesimals joseph w dauben

the politics of infinitesimals thus extended beyond technical mathematics they became emblematic of debates over abstraction rigor and the social function of science infinitesimals foundations philosophy of mathematics marx mao and mathematics the politics of infinitesimals joseph w dauben

expressions like lim h to 0 frac f x h f x h represent the culmination of centuries of effort to clarify the foundations of calculus limits calculus real analysis marx mao and mathematics the politics of infinitesimals joseph w dauben

the reflections which form the subject of this little treatise date from the autumn of the year 1858 i formed the fixed resolve to reflect until i had found a purely arithmetical and completely rigorous foundation for the principles of infinitesimal analysis real analysis foundations real numbers continuity and irrational numbers richard dedekind
by arithmetic i understand the science of numbers subtraction and division shall always be possible foundations real numbers continuity and irrational numbers richard dedekind
the rational numbers form an ordered field but they do not suffice to express every magnitude real numbers real analysis continuity and irrational numbers richard dedekind
let d be a positive integer which is not the square of an integer no rational number whose square equals d exists dedekind cuts real numbers continuity and irrational numbers richard dedekind
if all points of a straight line fall into two classes there exists one and only one point which produces this division dedekind cuts real analysis continuity and irrational numbers richard dedekind
every cut of the rational numbers determines either a rational or an irrational number dedekind cuts real numbers continuity and irrational numbers richard dedekind
whenever a cut is given which is not produced by a rational number we create a new number dedekind cuts real numbers continuity and irrational numbers richard dedekind
the totality of all real numbers forms a complete ordered field real numbers real analysis continuity and irrational numbers richard dedekind
if alpha and beta are real numbers corresponding to cuts their sum is defined by a corresponding cut real numbers dedekind cuts continuity and irrational numbers richard dedekind
the order of the real numbers is such that if alpha beta and beta gamma then alpha gamma real numbers real analysis continuity and irrational numbers richard dedekind

if s be a divisor of n then there is a conjugate divisor s such that ss n thus we see that the number of divisors from 1 to sqrt n is equal to the number of divisors from sqrt n to n number theory divisors ramanujan on the number of divisors of a number srinivasa ramanujan

let n p 1 a 1 p 2 a 2 dots p n a n where p 1 p 2 dots p n are primes then it is easy to see that d n 1 a 1 1 a 2 dots 1 a n number theory divisor function prime factorization on the number of divisors of a number srinivasa ramanujan

since the arithmetic mean of unequal positive numbers is always greater than their geometric mean we obtain inequalities which give a superior limit for d n number theory inequalities asymptotics on the number of divisors of a number srinivasa ramanujan

if p be the largest prime not exceeding x then bounds for d n may be expressed in terms of the product log 2 log 3 log 5 dots log p number theory primes bounds on the number of divisors of a number srinivasa ramanujan

the symbol o is used in the following sense f x o phi x means that there is a positive constant k such that f x leq k phi x for all sufficiently large values of x number theory asymptotics big o notation on the number of divisors of a number srinivasa ramanujan
